Getting Started

¶ Authors: Brian Schilder, Alan Murphy ¶

¶ Vignette updated: Nov-08-2022 ¶

Source: vignettes/rworkflows.Rmd
rworkflows.Rmd
library(rworkflows)

Examples

1. Create your R package

If you haven’t already created your R package, you can use templateR as a CRAN/Bioconductor-ready template.

2. Setup GitHub Secrets

GitHub now lets you store “Secrets” within each repo. These are basically hidden variables that no one but the repo admins can see/edit.

See here for instructions on how to create GitHub Secrets and GitHub Organization Secrets.

You will need to store the following variables as Secrets in your GitHub repo.

  • PAT_GITHUB: <Your GitHub Personal Authentication Token generated via the following instructions>
  • DOCKER_TOKEN: <Your DockerHub access token generated via the following instructions>

3. Create workflow file

rworkflows is also an R package that contains helper functions for setting up GHA workflows in your R package directory.

if(!require("rworkflows")) remotes::install_github("neurogenomics/rworkflows")
path <- rworkflows::use_gha()

4. Push to GitHub

Now, these workflows will automatically be run every time you push changes to your GitHub repo.

git add .
git commit -m "Added GHA workflow via rworkflows::use_gha()"
git push

You can then monitor the progress and view the results of your workflows via the “Actions” tab of your GitHub repo.

NOTE: If you do not see an “Actions” tab, go to Settings –> Actions and make sure “Actions permissions” is activated.
